elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="simple-para0025" view="all">A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bbbm)](CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> has been prepared and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> value of 1.38×10<ce:sup loc="post">−17</ce:sup> m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)2(bbbm)](CH3OH)2} n  has been prepared and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with n 2 value of 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0030" view="all">A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bbbm)](CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (bbbm=1,1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-benzimidazole) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a one-dimensional single helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> value of 1.38×10<ce:sup loc="post">−17</ce:sup> m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)2(bbbm)](CH3OH)2} n  (1) (bbbm=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzimidazole) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a one-dimensional single helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with n 2 value of 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0005" view="all">Polymeric complexes formed through the deliberate selection of metal ions and multifunctional ligands have recently received considerable attention in material chemistry, since they demonstrate intriguing network topologies and generate new class of materials with potential functions as electrical conductors , molecular magnets  and antibacterial agents . Nowadays, although the research on polymeric complexes is at a rapidly developing stage, the rational design for them is still a major challenge facing chemists. The rigid <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donor ligands have been intensively employed and provided a variety of topological architectures . Meanwhile, building infinite frameworks by using flexible bi- or multi-dentate bridging ligands and metal centers has also become an important area receiving much interest .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Polymeric complexes formed through the deliberate selection of metal ions and multifunctional ligands have recently received considerable attention in material chemistry, since they demonstrate intriguing network topologies and generate new class of materials with potential functions as electrical conductors , molecular magnets  and antibacterial agents . Nowadays, although the research on polymeric complexes is at a rapidly developing stage, the rational design for them is still a major challenge facing chemists. The rigid N-donor ligands have been intensively employed and provided a variety of topological architectures . Meanwhile, building infinite frameworks by using flexible bi- or multi-dentate bridging ligands and metal centers has also become an important area receiving much interest .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0010" view="all">Furthermore, the third-order NLO materials are currently of interest to a large number of research groups as they can be used for a number of photonic applications, for example, optical signal processing, optical communication, etc. . In principle, compared with traditional NLO material, the incorporation of metal atoms in coordination polymers introduces more sublevels into the energy hierarchy, which permits more allowed electronic transition to take place and hence generates a larger NLO effect . In the previous literature, we have reported the strong third-order nonlinear optical properties of d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> transition metal coordination polymers [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>, [Cd(bbbt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (bbbt=1,1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-benzotriazole) and [Zn(pbbt)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (pbbt=1,1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-(1,3-propylene)bis-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-benzotriazole) . It was expected that the combination of d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>transition metal with flexible bis-benzotriazole-type or bis-benzimidazole-type bridging ligands would exhibit intriguing structures and the strong third-order NLO properties. Based on the above considerations, bbbm (1,1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-benzimidazole) was selected as a bridge ligand in this work. Successfully, we have achieved a novel 1-D helical chain coordination polymer {[Zn(bbbm)(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), and studied its crystal structure and the third-order NLO property.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the third-order NLO materials are currently of interest to a large number of research groups as they can be used for a number of photonic applications, for example, optical signal processing, optical communication, etc. . In principle, compared with traditional NLO material, the incorporation of metal atoms in coordination polymers introduces more sublevels into the energy hierarchy, which permits more allowed electronic transition to take place and hence generates a larger NLO effect . In the previous literature, we have reported the strong third-order nonlinear optical properties of d10 transition metal coordination polymers [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n , [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2] n  (bbbt=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole) and [Zn(pbbt)(NCS)2] n  (pbbt=1,1'-(1,3-propylene)bis-1H-benzotriazole) . It was expected that the combination of d10transition metal with flexible bis-benzotriazole-type or bis-benzimidazole-type bridging ligands would exhibit intriguing structures and the strong third-order NLO properties. Based on the above considerations, bbbm (1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzimidazole) was selected as a bridge ligand in this work. Successfully, we have achieved a novel 1-D helical chain coordination polymer {[Zn(bbbm)(Ac)2](CH3OH)2} n  (1), and studied its crystal structure and the third-order NLO property.

elements.content: The polymer was synthesized by Zn(Ac)2 ·2H2O reacting with bbbm 1 Anal. Calc. for C18H18N4 (bbbm) (%): C, 74.48; H, 6.25; N, 19.30. Found: C, 74.68; H, 6.38; N, 19.43%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 3083m, 2924m, 1496s, 1462s, 1383s, 1332s, 751s. 1H NMR (chloroform): δ 8.119 (2H), 7.816–7.839 (2H), 7.263–7.359 (6H), 4.225 (4H), 1.932–1.955 (4H). (prepared according to the literature ) in the mole ratio of 1:2 for one week in 10 ml methanol solution at room temperature. The yield is 55%. The colorless crystals of 1 are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. 2 Anal. Calc. for C24H32N4O6Zn: C, 53.54; H, 5.95; N, 10.41%. Found: C, 53.48; H, 5.98; N, 10.44%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 3098m, 2952m, 2069s, 1598s, 1520m, 1392s, 1332m, 753s. Crystal data for 1: Fw, 537.91; triclinic; space group, P 1 ̄ ; cell dimensions: a=11.302(2) Å; b=14.126(3) Å; c=8.7536(18) Å; V=1313.8(5) Å3; Z=2; μ=9.26 cm−1; T=291(2) K. Reflections collected: 3442; independent reflections: 3442; Final R indices [I>2δ(I)]: R a=0.0520, R w=0.1191. All data were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The data were collected at a temperature of 18±1 °C and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. All calculations were performed using the . The coordination environment around the Zn atom is given in . The crystal structure is made up of [Zn(bbbm)(Ac)2] and non-coordinated methanol molecular. The Zn(II) center is in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with two nitrogen atoms from two bbbm groups and two oxygen atoms from two monodentate acetate anions. The bond angles around the Zn(II) ion are in the range of 98.1(2)–116.8(2)°. Zn–Nbbbm bond lengths (2.006(4), 2.015(5) Å) correspond to those observed in [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n (average 2.025 Å) and [Zn(tp)(4,4-bipyridine)] (average 2.170 Å) (tp=terephthalate) . However, Zn–O bond lengths (1.933(4), 1.952(4) Å) are shorter than those reported polymers and those of Zn–N . Meanwhile, O(1)–Zn–O(3) and N(1)–Zn(1)–N(3) bond angles are 106.47(19)° and 108.93(19)°, respectively, indicating a slightly distortion. The bbbm ligands have two kinds of different twisted conformations during coordinating: the torsion angles are −61.2° and 61.2° for N2–C8–C9–C9A and C9–C9A–C8A–N2A, respectively; the torsion angles are −69.4° and 69.4° for N4–C17–C18–C18A and C18–C18A–C17A–N4A, respectively, showing that the two benzimidazole rings from one bbbm are parallel to each other. Each trans-bbbm bridges two zinc ions together via nitrogen atoms to form a 1-D single helical chain ( ). The helical features of this helix are defined by several parameters. The planar index of planes Zn1–N1–C4–C8 (1), C8–C9–C9A–C8A (2) are 0.0011 and 0.0000 Å, respectively. The dihedral angle between planes (1) and (2) is 103.1°. One Zn(II) atom, one bbbm ligand and two Ac−anions consist of a replicating structure unit. The intrachain Zn⋯Zn separation is 11.928 Å.
elements.clean_text: The polymer was synthesized by Zn(Ac)2 ⋅2H2O reacting with bbbm 1  Anal. Calc. for C18H18N4 (bbbm) (%): C, 74.48; H, 6.25; N, 19.30. Found: C, 74.68; H, 6.38; N, 19.43%. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3083m, 2924m, 1496s, 1462s, 1383s, 1332s, 751s. 1H NMR (chloroform): δ 8.119 (2H), 7.816-7.839 (2H), 7.263-7.359 (6H), 4.225 (4H), 1.932-1.955 (4H).   (prepared according to the literature ) in the mole ratio of 1:2 for one week in 10 ml methanol solution at room temperature. The yield is 55%. The colorless crystals of 1 are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. 2  Anal. Calc. for C24H32N4O6Zn: C, 53.54; H, 5.95; N, 10.41%. Found: C, 53.48; H, 5.98; N, 10.44%. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3098m, 2952m, 2069s, 1598s, 1520m, 1392s, 1332m, 753s. Crystal data for 1: Fw, 537.91; triclinic; space group, P 1 ̄  ; cell dimensions: a=11.302(2) Å; b=14.126(3) Å; c=8.7536(18) Å; V=1313.8(5) Å3; Z=2; μ=9.26 cm-1; T=291(2) K. Reflections collected: 3442; independent reflections: 3442; Final R indices [I>2δ(I)]: R a=0.0520, R w=0.1191. All data were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The data were collected at a temperature of 18±1 °C and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. All calculations were performed using the  .   The coordination environment around the Zn atom is given in  . The crystal structure is made up of [Zn(bbbm)(Ac)2] and non-coordinated methanol molecular. The Zn(II) center is in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with two nitrogen atoms from two bbbm groups and two oxygen atoms from two monodentate acetate anions. The bond angles around the Zn(II) ion are in the range of 98.1(2)-116.8(2)°. Zn-Nbbbm bond lengths (2.006(4), 2.015(5) Å) correspond to those observed in [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n  (average 2.025 Å) and [Zn(tp)(4,4-bipyridine)] (average 2.170 Å) (tp=terephthalate) . However, Zn-O bond lengths (1.933(4), 1.952(4) Å) are shorter than those reported polymers and those of Zn-N . Meanwhile, O(1)-Zn-O(3) and N(1)-Zn(1)-N(3) bond angles are 106.47(19)° and 108.93(19)°, respectively, indicating a slightly distortion. The bbbm ligands have two kinds of different twisted conformations during coordinating: the torsion angles are -61.2° and 61.2° for N2-C8-C9-C9A and C9-C9A-C8A-N2A, respectively; the torsion angles are -69.4° and 69.4° for N4-C17-C18-C18A and C18-C18A-C17A-N4A, respectively, showing that the two benzimidazole rings from one bbbm are parallel to each other. Each trans-bbbm bridges two zinc ions together via nitrogen atoms to form a 1-D single helical chain ( ). The helical features of this helix are defined by several parameters. The planar index of planes Zn1-N1-C4-C8 (1), C8-C9-C9A-C8A (2) are 0.0011 and 0.0000 Å, respectively. The dihedral angle between planes (1) and (2) is 103.1°. One Zn(II) atom, one bbbm ligand and two Ac-anions consist of a replicating structure unit. The intrachain Zn⋯Zn separation is 11.928 Å.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0020" view="all">The thermal property of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated using simultaneously thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analyses (DTA) investigations. The TG curve of the polymer exhibits three continuous weight loss stages in the ranges of 37–93, 93–390 and 390–677 °C, corresponding to the concomitant release of the crystallized methanol molecule, decompositions of the Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and bbbm. There are three weak endothermic peaks (69, 125 and 263 °C) and one very strong exothermic peak (515 °C) on the DTA curve.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermal property of polymer 1 was investigated using simultaneously thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analyses (DTA) investigations. The TG curve of the polymer exhibits three continuous weight loss stages in the ranges of 37-93, 93-390 and 390-677 °C, corresponding to the concomitant release of the crystallized methanol molecule, decompositions of the Ac- anions and bbbm. There are three weak endothermic peaks (69, 125 and 263 °C) and one very strong exothermic peak (515 °C) on the DTA curve.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0025" view="all">The UV–Vis spectrum of the polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows that it has relatively low linear absorption in the visible and near-IR region, which is similar to the behavior of other coordination polymers . The NLO property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is measured in a 1.7×10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup> mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> DMF solution by Z-scan technique.<ce:footnote id="FN3">
<ce:label>3</ce:label>
<ce:note-para>The NLO properties were measured with a linearly polarized laser light (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=532 nm; pulse widths=7 ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd:YAG laser. An aperture of 0.5 mm in radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>
 It exhibits weak NLO absorptive and strong NLO refractive properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The UV-Vis spectrum of the polymer 1 shows that it has relatively low linear absorption in the visible and near-IR region, which is similar to the behavior of other coordination polymers . The NLO property of 1 is measured in a 1.7×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution by Z-scan technique. 3 The NLO properties were measured with a linearly polarized laser light (λ=532 nm; pulse widths=7 ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd:YAG laser. An aperture of 0.5 mm in radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.   It exhibits weak NLO absorptive and strong NLO refractive properties.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0035" view="all">

<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is better than some best performing NLO materials such as inorganic oxides like SiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>), semiconductors like CdS (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=2.5×10<ce:sup loc="post">−18</ce:sup> m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>), and organic polymers like DANS (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . It is obvious that polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits stronger NLO refractive effect, which can match those of the best-known third-order NLO materials in neat solid form. Moreover, its <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> value is also comparable to those of cluster compounds like [W<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(AsPh<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: depicts NLO refractive property of polymer 1. A reasonably good fit between the experimental data (black dot) and the theoretical curves (solids curves) based on Eqs.  was obtained. The refractive index n 2 was calculated to be 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which shows that the polymer has a positive sign for the refractive nonlinearity. The valley/peak pattern of the normalized transmittance curve shows characteristic self-focusing behavior. The n 2 is better than some best performing NLO materials such as inorganic oxides like SiO2 (n 2=2×10-20 m2 W-1), semiconductors like CdS (n 2=2.5×10-18 m2 W-1), and organic polymers like DANS (n 2=8×10-18 m2 W-1) . It is obvious that polymer 1 exhibits stronger NLO refractive effect, which can match those of the best-known third-order NLO materials in neat solid form. Moreover, its n 2 value is also comparable to those of cluster compounds like [W2Ag4S8(AsPh3)4] (n 2=5.9×10-16 m2 W-1) , {[Et4N]2[MoS4Cu4(CN)4]} n  (n 2=1.8×10-16 m2 W-1)  and our reported coordination polymers like [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n  (n 2=4.53×10-18 m2 W-1), [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2] n  (n 2=3.07×10-19 m2 W-1) and [Zn(pbbt)(NCS)2] n  (n 2=3.02×10-18 m2 W-1).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0040" view="all">The third-order NLO susceptibility <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">(3)</ce:sup> values of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be calculated from the equation |<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">(3)</ce:sup>|=<ce:italic>cn</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/80π , where <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> is speed of light in vacuum, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is linear refractive indexes of the sample. Its <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">(3)</ce:sup> value is 3.23×10<ce:sup loc="post">−11</ce:sup> esu. The results show that polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possess strong third-order nonlinear optical properties and will become promising candidates for NLO materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The third-order NLO susceptibility χ (3) values of polymer 1 can be calculated from the equation |χ (3)|=cn 0 2 n 2/80π , where c is speed of light in vacuum, n 0 is linear refractive indexes of the sample. Its χ (3) value is 3.23×10-11 esu. The results show that polymer 1 possess strong third-order nonlinear optical properties and will become promising candidates for NLO materials.

cln_elements.content: The polymer was synthesized by Zn(Ac)2 ·2H2O reacting with bbbm 1 Anal. Calc. for C18H18N4 (bbbm) (%): C, 74.48; H, 6.25; N, 19.30. Found: C, 74.68; H, 6.38; N, 19.43%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 3083m, 2924m, 1496s, 1462s, 1383s, 1332s, 751s. 1H NMR (chloroform): δ 8.119 (2H), 7.816–7.839 (2H), 7.263–7.359 (6H), 4.225 (4H), 1.932–1.955 (4H). (prepared according to the literature ) in the mole ratio of 1:2 for one week in 10 ml methanol solution at room temperature. The yield is 55%. The colorless crystals of 1 are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. 2 Anal. Calc. for C24H32N4O6Zn: C, 53.54; H, 5.95; N, 10.41%. Found: C, 53.48; H, 5.98; N, 10.44%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 3098m, 2952m, 2069s, 1598s, 1520m, 1392s, 1332m, 753s. Crystal data for 1: Fw, 537.91; triclinic; space group, P 1 ̄ ; cell dimensions: a=11.302(2) Å; b=14.126(3) Å; c=8.7536(18) Å; V=1313.8(5) Å3; Z=2; μ=9.26 cm−1; T=291(2) K. Reflections collected: 3442; independent reflections: 3442; Final R indices [I>2δ(I)]: R a=0.0520, R w=0.1191. All data were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The data were collected at a temperature of 18±1 °C and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. All calculations were performed using the . The coordination environment around the Zn atom is given in . The crystal structure is made up of [Zn(bbbm)(Ac)2] and non-coordinated methanol molecular. The Zn(II) center is in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with two nitrogen atoms from two bbbm groups and two oxygen atoms from two monodentate acetate anions. The bond angles around the Zn(II) ion are in the range of 98.1(2)–116.8(2)°. Zn–Nbbbm bond lengths (2.006(4), 2.015(5) Å) correspond to those observed in [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n (average 2.025 Å) and [Zn(tp)(4,4-bipyridine)] (average 2.170 Å) (tp=terephthalate) . However, Zn–O bond lengths (1.933(4), 1.952(4) Å) are shorter than those reported polymers and those of Zn–N . Meanwhile, O(1)–Zn–O(3) and N(1)–Zn(1)–N(3) bond angles are 106.47(19)° and 108.93(19)°, respectively, indicating a slightly distortion. The bbbm ligands have two kinds of different twisted conformations during coordinating: the torsion angles are −61.2° and 61.2° for N2–C8–C9–C9A and C9–C9A–C8A–N2A, respectively; the torsion angles are −69.4° and 69.4° for N4–C17–C18–C18A and C18–C18A–C17A–N4A, respectively, showing that the two benzimidazole rings from one bbbm are parallel to each other. Each trans-bbbm bridges two zinc ions together via nitrogen atoms to form a 1-D single helical chain ( ). The helical features of this helix are defined by several parameters. The planar index of planes Zn1–N1–C4–C8 (1), C8–C9–C9A–C8A (2) are 0.0011 and 0.0000 Å, respectively. The dihedral angle between planes (1) and (2) is 103.1°. One Zn(II) atom, one bbbm ligand and two Ac−anions consist of a replicating structure unit. The intrachain Zn⋯Zn separation is 11.928 Å.

IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3083m, 2924m, 1496s, 1462s, 1383s, 1332s, 751s. 1H NMR (chloroform): δ 8.119 (2H), 7.816-7.839 (2H), 7.263-7.359 (6H), 4.225 (4H), 1.932-1.955 (4H).   (prepared according to the literature ) in the mole ratio of 1:2 for one week in 10 ml methanol solution at room temperature. The yield is 55%. The colorless crystals of 1 are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. 2  Anal. Calc. for C24H32N4O6Zn: C, 53.54; H, 5.95; N, 10.41%. Found: C, 53.48; H, 5.98; N, 10.44%. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3098m, 2952m, 2069s, 1598s, 1520m, 1392s, 1332m, 753s. Crystal data for 1: Fw, 537.91; triclinic; space group, P 1 ̄  ; cell dimensions: a=11.302(2) Å; b=14.126(3) Å; c=8.7536(18) Å; V=1313.8(5) Å3; Z=2; μ=9.26 cm-1; T=291(2) K. Reflections collected: 3442; independent reflections: 3442; Final R indices [I>2δ(I)]: R a=0.0520, R w=0.1191. All data were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The data were collected at a temperature of 18±1 °C and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. All calculations were performed using the  .   The coordination environment around the Zn atom is given in  . The crystal structure is made up of [Zn(bbbm)(Ac)2] and non-coordinated methanol molecular. The Zn(II) center is in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with two nitrogen atoms from two bbbm groups and two oxygen atoms from two monodentate acetate anions. The bond angles around the Zn(II) ion are in the range of 98.1(2)-116.8(2)°. Zn-Nbbbm bond lengths (2.006(4), 2.015(5) Å) correspond to those observed in [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n  (average 2.025 Å) and [Zn(tp)(4,4-bipyridine)] (average 2.170 Å) (tp=terephthalate) . However, Zn-O bond lengths (1.933(4), 1.952(4) Å) are shorter than those reported polymers and those of Zn-N . Meanwhile, O(1)-Zn-O(3) and N(1)-Zn(1)-N(3) bond angles are 106.47(19)° and 108.93(19)°, respectively, indicating a slightly distortion. The bbbm ligands have two kinds of different twisted conformations during coordinating: the torsion angles are -61.2° and 61.2° for N2-C8-C9-C9A and C9-C9A-C8A-N2A, respectively; the torsion angles are -69.4° and 69.4° for N4-C17-C18-C18A and C18-C18A-C17A-N4A, respectively, showing that the two benzimidazole rings from one bbbm are parallel to each other. Each trans-bbbm bridges two zinc ions together via nitrogen atoms to form a 1-D single helical chain ( ). The helical features of this helix are defined by several parameters. The planar index of planes Zn1-N1-C4-C8 (1), C8-C9-C9A-C8A (2) are 0.0011 and 0.0000 Å, respectively. The dihedral angle between planes (1) and (2) is 103.1°. One Zn(II) atom, one bbbm ligand and two Ac-anions consist of a replicating structure unit. The intrachain Zn⋯Zn separation is 11.928 Å.

cln_elements.clean_text:
A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)2(bbbm)](CH3OH)2} n  has been prepared and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with n 2 value of 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.

Abstract

A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)2(bbbm)](CH3OH)2} n  (1) (bbbm=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzimidazole) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a one-dimensional single helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with n 2 value of 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.

The thermal property of polymer 1 was investigated using simultaneously thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analyses (DTA) investigations. The TG curve of the polymer exhibits three continuous weight loss stages in the ranges of 37-93, 93-390 and 390-677 °C, corresponding to the concomitant release of the crystallized methanol molecule, decompositions of the Ac- anions and bbbm. There are three weak endothermic peaks (69, 125 and 263 °C) and one very strong exothermic peak (515 °C) on the DTA curve.

The UV-Vis spectrum of the polymer 1 shows that it has relatively low linear absorption in the visible and near-IR region, which is similar to the behavior of other coordination polymers . The NLO property of 1 is measured in a 1.7×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution by Z-scan technique. 3 The NLO properties were measured with a linearly polarized laser light (λ=532 nm; pulse widths=7 ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd:YAG laser. An aperture of 0.5 mm in radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.   It exhibits weak NLO absorptive and strong NLO refractive properties.

   depicts NLO refractive property of polymer 1. A reasonably good fit between the experimental data (black dot) and the theoretical curves (solids curves) based on Eqs.  was obtained. The refractive index n 2 was calculated to be 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which shows that the polymer has a positive sign for the refractive nonlinearity. The valley/peak pattern of the normalized transmittance curve shows characteristic self-focusing behavior. The n 2 is better than some best performing NLO materials such as inorganic oxides like SiO2 (n 2=2×10-20 m2 W-1), semiconductors like CdS (n 2=2.5×10-18 m2 W-1), and organic polymers like DANS (n 2=8×10-18 m2 W-1) . It is obvious that polymer 1 exhibits stronger NLO refractive effect, which can match those of the best-known third-order NLO materials in neat solid form. Moreover, its n 2 value is also comparable to those of cluster compounds like [W2Ag4S8(AsPh3)4] (n 2=5.9×10-16 m2 W-1) , {[Et4N]2[MoS4Cu4(CN)4]} n  (n 2=1.8×10-16 m2 W-1)  and our reported coordination polymers like [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n  (n 2=4.53×10-18 m2 W-1), [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2] n  (n 2=3.07×10-19 m2 W-1) and [Zn(pbbt)(NCS)2] n  (n 2=3.02×10-18 m2 W-1).

The third-order NLO susceptibility χ (3) values of polymer 1 can be calculated from the equation |χ (3)|=cn 0 2 n 2/80π , where c is speed of light in vacuum, n 0 is linear refractive indexes of the sample. Its χ (3) value is 3.23×10-11 esu. The results show that polymer 1 possess strong third-order nonlinear optical properties and will become promising candidates for NLO materials.

decomposition temperature.type: release of the crystallized methanol molecule
decompositions of the Ac− anions and bbbm

equation.parameters: c is speed of light in vacuum, n0 is linear refractive indexes of the sample
